summary: This document is a chain of emails from June 2020 between FBI personnel and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) discussing the processing and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The emails focus on logistical challenges, data formats, and the need to produce evidence in a usable format for discovery and taint review. This document is a series of emails from February 2020 between the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) and the FBI's New York office, discussing the organization and transfer of digital evidence from search warrants executed in the Epstein case. The emails focus on tracking devices seized from Epstein's New York mansion and Virgin Islands residence, coordinating data transfers, and planning a meeting to ensure proper handling of the evidence.

events.title: Email coordination on evidence processing
events.description: FBI and US Attorney's Office personnel exchange emails about the status of imaging and processing digital evidence from Epstein search warrants.

events.title: Update on evidence processing delays
events.description: FBI informs the US Attorney's Office that recent events and staffing levels have caused delays in processing evidence, pushing back estimates by 1-2 weeks.

events.title: Submission of updated evidence descriptions
events.description: FBI sends updated item descriptions for seized digital evidence, including electronically reported serial numbers for thumb drives and SD cards.

events.title: Listing of evidence gathered in NY
events.description: FBI provides a comprehensive list of all evidence gathered in New York, detailing device types, data sizes, and transfer status.

events.title: Planning of evidence coordination call
events.description: FBI and US Attorney's Office schedule a conference call to discuss outstanding issues regarding the list of seized devices and evidence processing.

events.title: Report of significant evidence review problems
events.description: US Attorney's Office details major problems with previously received evidence, including inability to link emails to attachments and mismatched load files, rendering over 1 million documents difficult to review.

events.title: Listing of previously handed over evidence
events.description: FBI provides a list of evidence already transferred to the US Attorney's Office, noting the processing of duplicate hard drives and inclusion of loose media and Windows machines from the NY apartment.

events.title: Coordination on Epstein Evidence Transfer
events.description: Email exchange between the U.S. Attorney's Office and the FBI regarding the status of digital evidence from Epstein search warrants, planning a meeting to get organized.

keyFacts: The FBI's Computer Analysis Response Team (CART) was processing terabytes of digital evidence seized from Epstein's properties in New York and the US Virgin Islands, including phones, tablets, media, cameras, DVRs, servers, and computers.

Significant problems were reported with over 1 million previously produced documents, including an inability to link emails to their attachments and mismatched load files that made review and future production to defense counsel difficult.
Evidence seized included 9 IDE hard drives from Epstein's Manhattan apartment, which were determined to be 3 copies of 3 drives from a July 2007 search of one of his properties.

The U.S. Attorney's Office required evidence in a specific format loadable onto the Relativity database for taint review and discovery purposes, which the FBI noted added months of work and was incapable of viewing all forensic data.

Processing was delayed due to reduced staffing levels (down to one day a week for some personnel) and the logistical challenges of transferring massive amounts of data during the COVID-19 pandemic period.
Digital evidence from Epstein search warrants included approximately 40+ devices from a New York mansion and 25+ devices from the Virgin Islands, including servers.
The FBI was processing over a million documents from the seized devices, indicating the massive scale of the digital evidence collection.
Coordination issues existed between the U.S. Attorney's Office and the FBI regarding tracking which devices had been examined and which data had been transferred.
Evidence from the New York search included Windows-based items, loose media, and CDs containing only pictures (no documents), with some Apple items still pending production.
